Kronus

The University of Kansas has announced that it intends to start teaching Intelligent Design. In a mythology class. "Special Topics in Religion: Intelligent Design, Creationism and other Religious Mythologies". Apparently the school got fed up and wanted to show that there are some intelligent people in Kansas.
 
 http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10153657/
pandion
Thank you. I already reported it HERE. No reaction from creationists.
Ooaman

Okay, in defense of my school (KU) isn't creation (Intelligent Design-which I have to question that title since it has been mostly Bush pushing for it) a religion thing? Science is supposed to tell how something happens (happened). The creation story in the (Christian/Jewish/Islamic) Bible does not tell how. It tells more of a why or what. It was never intended to be about how God did anything. I specify the creation story here (which these three are the exact same beginning because they are the exact same God) because when people say ID, they are referring mostly to the creation in Genesis. All you get is a poetry reading almost of what happened. (And then God did such and such.) There is a difference between What happened and How it happened. There is nothing scientific about it at all. There is nothing wrong with teaching it in a religions class or some kind of social studies class.

Islam, Judaism, and Christianity do not have the same God. Christianity holds that Jesus is God, but neither of the other two religions do.

 Christianity holds that Jesus is the "Son of" God. Jesus was Jewish and so the Christian God is the same as the Jewish God. People of the Islam faith say that Abraham was the first Muslim. That's Abraham from Genesis. The only difference is that the people of the Jewish and Islamic faith don't believe Jesus was anything more than a prophet of God. The Old Testament of the Christian Bible Is the Jewish Bible. And in many ways, the Islamic Bible reflects on those stories. But the God is the same in all 3 faiths.

If Jesus was God and not The Son of God, then why did he always refer to God as "Father" rather than "hey, myself?"

 
 Because he is part of the trinity that makes up God. God has 3 parts:
 1) The Father
 2) The Son
 3) The Holy Spirit
 
 Three parts of a whole. 
 
 Jesus (the Son) was speaking to The Father through the grace of the Holy Spirit.
 
 If it sounds confusing then you probably understand it as well as you ever will.
 
 If it makes sense to you then you probably don't understand what I am saying.

 First of all, let me apologize for taking this into a tangent that should probably be on the Religious forum.
 Second, I do understand this. What I was commenting on was that DamEtel said that the Christian faith stands that Jesus IS God. My saying that he is considered the "Son of" God was that he wasn't God but in part was a part of God. However, my original point was that the three religions have the same creation story because the core religion comes from the same place. In fact, many of the early leaders of the Christian church insisted that you had to be Jewish before you could be Christian. Then when the Islamic faith got started (around 611 AD) it was a mixture of the two and the Arabian religions turned monotheistic. In many respects, (many more than some are willing to say) the 3 religions parallel the others in some ways.

 But Christians hold that Jesus IS God. That's what I was taught as a baptist (both as child and many years later in a different church in a different state), and one can Google for phrases such as "Jesus is God" and "God in the flesh" to find support: here are a few hits I got.
